evals.prompt: I need to implement a function that validates email addresses. Use TDD. The project uses Python with pytest. There's a pyproject.toml in the root.
evals.expected_output: A TDD cycle showing RED-GREEN-REFACTOR phases with actual pytest syntax, starting with degenerate cases
expectations: The skill detects Python/pytest as the test stack in Step 0
The skill uses pytest syntax (def test_, assert) not generic pseudocode
The first test is a degenerate case (empty string, None, or similar), not the happy path
Each RED phase shows a failing test before any production code is written
Each GREEN phase shows minimum code to pass — not the complete validation logic upfront
The REFACTOR phase applies naming and functions skills, not just 'clean up'
The cycle time feels incremental — not one massive test followed by one massive implementation
The skill does NOT explain what TDD is or why it matters — it just executes the cycle

evals.expected_output: Identified issues with severity levels: multiple Act phases (red flag), vague test name (warning), tests behavior through multiple operations
expectations: The skill detects TypeScript/Jest as the stack
The skill identifies multiple Act-Assert sequences as a red flag (AAA violation)
The skill identifies the vague test name 'user test' as an issue
The skill suggests splitting into separate tests with descriptive names
Issues are classified by severity (red flag / warning / improve)
The skill uses Jest/TypeScript syntax in its suggestions, not pseudocode
